name: Aortic Stenosis - Diagnosis and Management
content:
AORTIC STENOSIS (AS):

DEFINITION:
- Narrowing of aortic valve orifice
- Obstruction to LV outflow

ETIOLOGY:
- Degenerative/calcific (most common, elderly)
- Bicuspid aortic valve (younger patients)
- Rheumatic (rare in developed countries)

CLASSIC TRIAD (Late symptoms):
1. Exertional dyspnea (HF)
2. Angina (myocardial O2 supply-demand mismatch)
3. Syncope (exertional, due to fixed CO)

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur
- Radiates to carotids
- Diminished/delayed carotid upstrokes (pulsus parvus et tardus)
- Paradoxical splitting S2 (if severe)
- S4 gallop

ECHOCARDIOGRAPHIC CRITERIA:

Severity grading:

Mild AS:
- Aortic jet velocity: 2.6-2.9 m/s
- Mean gradient: <20 mmHg
- Valve area: >1.5 cm²

Moderate AS:
- Velocity: 3.0-3.9 m/s
- Mean gradient: 20-39 mmHg
- Valve area: 1.0-1.5 cm²

Severe AS:
- Velocity: ≥4.0 m/s
- Mean gradient: ≥40 mmHg
- Valve area: <1.0 cm² (or indexed area <0.6 cm²/m²)

Very Severe AS:
- Velocity: ≥5.0 m/s
- Mean gradient: ≥60 mmHg
- Valve area: <0.75 cm²

Additional assessment:
- LV function (LVEF)
- LV hypertrophy
- Degree of calcification

STAGING (ACC/AHA 2020):

Stage A: At risk
- Bicuspid AoV, sclerosis
- Asymptomatic, normal hemodynamics

Stage B: Progressive
- Mild-moderate AS
- Asymptomatic

Stage C: Asymptomatic severe AS
- C1: LVEF >50%
- C2: LVEF <50%

Stage D: Symptomatic severe AS
- D1: High gradient (≥40 mmHg)
- D2: Low-flow/low-gradient with reduced LVEF
- D3: Low-flow/low-gradient with normal LVEF (paradoxical)

NATURAL HISTORY:
- Asymptomatic severe AS: 2-5 years to symptoms
- Once symptoms: Survival 2-3 years without intervention
- Sudden cardiac death: 1% per year if asymptomatic, much higher if symptomatic

INDICATIONS FOR INTERVENTION:

1. Symptomatic severe AS (Class I)
2. Asymptomatic severe AS with:
   - LVEF <50%
   - Undergoing other cardiac surgery
   - Very severe AS (velocity ≥5 m/s)
   - Rapid progression (velocity increase ≥0.3 m/s/year)
   - BNP >3× normal
   - Abnormal exercise test

TREATMENT OPTIONS:

1. SURGICAL AVR (SAVR):
   - Mechanical valve (requires lifelong anticoagulation)
   - Bioprosthetic valve (no anticoagulation, but limited durability 10-20 years)
   - Indications: Low surgical risk, younger age, other cardiac surgery needed

2. TRANSCATHETER AVR (TAVR):
   - Less invasive, transfemoral or transapical approach
   - Now approved for all risk categories
   - Preferred if high surgical risk, elderly >80
   - Complications: Vascular injury, stroke, paravalvular leak, conduction abnormalities (may need PPM)

3. BALLOON VALVULOPLASTY:
   - Palliative only (high restenosis rate)
   - Bridge to AVR or destination if not candidate

MEDICAL MANAGEMENT:
- No medications slow AS progression
- Treat hypertension cautiously (avoid aggressive BP lowering)
- Avoid strenuous activity if symptomatic severe AS
- Serial echo surveillance:
  * Mild AS: Every 3-5 years
  * Moderate AS: Every 1-2 years
  * Severe asymptomatic: Every 6-12 months

COMPLICATIONS:
- Heart failure (most common)
- Sudden cardiac death
- Syncope
- Gastrointestinal bleeding (Heyde syndrome: AVMs + AS)
- Endocarditis

PROGNOSIS:
- Excellent after AVR/TAVR (30-day mortality 1-3% for SAVR, 1-2% for TAVR)
- Poor without intervention if symptomatic (50% mortality at 2 years)
